title: Induced current - magnetic force on moving loop

content.question: A rectangular loop of conducting wire is moved with constant speed into a uniform magnetic field directed into the page. The width and length of the loop are <math alttext="2 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> and <math alttext="6 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>, respectively. The resistance of the loop is <math alttext="0.5 ohm" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Î©</mi></math>, the speed of the loop is always <math alttext="4 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>, and the magnitude of the magnetic field is <math alttext="1.5 tesla" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></math>. At time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the loop is halfway into the magnetic field, as shown. What is the magnitude of the magnetic force on the loop at time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
